It's PARTY time!!! PROST! 0 0 Days Days 0 0 Hrs Hours 0 0 Mins Minutes 0 0 Secs Seconds Celebrate Oktoberfest at Krush Brau Park PROST! Get ready for an authentic Oktoberfest experience right here in Kissimmee, Florida, at Krush Brau Park! While the traditional Oktoberfest festivities are held in Munich, Germany, you don't have to travel across the Atlantic to immerse yourself in the rich traditions and Bavarian charm. Join us at Krush Brau Park and indulge in all the beer, food, music, and fun that make Oktoberfest a beloved global celebration. A Taste of Bavaria in the Heart of Florida At Krush Brau Park, we've recreated the spirit of Munich's Oktoberfest to bring you an unforgettable experience. Adorned with traditional Bavarian d√©cor and vibrant Oktoberfest colors, sets the perfect backdrop for a memorable celebration. The aroma of freshly baked pretzels, bratwurst, and sauerkraut fills the air, transporting you straight to the heart of Bavaria. Our founder, Waylon Krush, served in the US Army and was stationed at Bad Aibling, Germany for 3 years. Ever since, it has been a dream of his to build a German-inspired beer garden to share with the American people. We welcome and give discounts to all our veterans and first responders. German influenced with American flair! Built on the abandoned 'Jungleland Zoo', we have revitalized this land to be a fun-filled experience for the whole family with food, beverages, live music and more! Read more about the history of the property below. Giving Back Knowing the history of the property, Krush Brau Park is all about giving back to the community and supporting animal charities. Please contact us if your organization would like to be included in our giving family. ‚ÄúWe can do no great things, only small things with great love.‚Äù ‚Äì Mother Teresa History of the Property Back in the late 1970s, Alligatorland Safari Zoo opened and featured over 1600 exotic animals and birds. Proving that competition was tough, in 1982, Gatorland Zoo filed suit against Alligatorland for attempting to build a strikingly similar entryway to theirs that resembled a gator‚Äôs open jaws, which Gatorland had since the 1960s. In 1990, Alligatorland Safari Zoo came under attack after they received a surprise inspection from the USDA and were charged with keeping inaccurate records, having poor sanitation and structural conditions in some of the cages, and having poor veterinary care for its animals. Darren Browning, the owner of Alligatorland, refused to acknowledge the USDA‚Äôs right to regulate his business, claiming the violations never existed or were quickly corrected and refused to pay a $1,500 fine. He characterized the fine as nothing more than a ploy by the USDA to punish them for refusing to erect a $20,000, 8-foot tall security fence to keep the wild animals from escaping. Browning chose to fight the fine at a two-day USDA hearing in November 1992, representing himself because he said he knows as much about exotic animal care as USDA inspectors, and it would have cost too much to hire an attorney. After losing consequent battles in court against the USDA, the Browning‚Äôs sold the property in 1995. Jungleland Zoo opened in 1995 and housed over 300 exotic animals, a large drop from Alligatorland which featured 1600 animals. The zoo was best known for its big cat shows which showcased different species of cats, from bobcats and lynxes to Bengal and Siberian tigers. During the winter of 1997, days of rainfall flooded the swamp, making it a dangerous situation for the caged animals. On December 15, while handlers tried to raise the cage of their 450-pound lioness above flooded ground, it escaped into the marsh. A search for Nala, named after a character from ‚ÄúThe Lion King‚Äù, was quickly initiated, ranging over the swamp along Hwy 192. Though wildlife agents were equipped with an infrared sensor attached to a helicopter and over 20 agents on the ground with tranquilizer guns and rifles, a canopy of lush vegetation and 4-foot-deep water, made it difficult to track her. Residents and tourists were put on alert, but Jungleland officials claimed that lioness was ‚Äúhand-raised, declawed and very sociable‚Äù. Finally, after two days, Nala was spotted just a few hundred yards from her cage at the zoo. Dr. James Barnett, a veterinarian, moved in but upon being spotted, Nala hissed and tried to hide under some bushes. Dr. Barnett fired two tranquilizer shots, missing with the first shot but finding its mark on the second. It took five minutes for Nala to become sedated, where Dr. Barnett injected her with more tranquilizer. In late-2002, Jungleland Zoo removed its animals from public view and had set all their gift shop stock at 50% off. The owners claimed they were another victim to the post-9/11 economy, but the local Channel 6 News reported the zoo was being investigated by the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission and the U.S. Department of Agriculture for possible violations of the Animal Welfare Act. A surprise inspection in June by state inspectors said the ‚Äúfacility is suffering from a severe drainage issue,‚Äù noting rotted cages and inadequate fence heights. The inspectors also reported that ‚Äúthe animals looked healthy.‚Äù The property was purchased by Patrick Clancy, founder, and owner of Jungle Habitat Preserve, an exotic animal sanctuary that cares for unwanted animals due to lack of funds or other reasons. Unfortunately, further money was needed to repair and modernize the property. The property was foreclosed in 2017 and later sold again at the end of 2018 to Jungleland Zoo Partners, LLC. In September 2020, Krush Acquisitions, a veteran owned company by Waylon and Katie Krush, purchased the property and will be revitalizing the former Jungleland Zoo to be a vibrant German-inspired biergarten (beer garden) and park. It will include a brewery, eateries, live music and attractions for families and kids alike with an outdoor theater, playgrounds, and a petting zoo. Waylon Krush, a veteran of the US Army, was stationed at Bad Aibling, Germany for 3 years. He traveled throughout all of Germany during his service and fell in love with the different beers, bakery goods, and festivals each state had to offer, especially attending Oktoberfest 3 years in a row. Ever since, it has been a dream of his to build a German-inspired beer garden to share with the American people. Krush Brau Park will have a beautiful 9,000+ square foot main building along with several container buildings to support food, beverage and entertainment. The facility and garden will be broken up to feature different countries around the world ¬†to highlight its cuisine, beers, and more. -- Source: https://www.abandonedfl.com/jungleland-zoo/ Copyright ¬© 2023 Krush Brau Park - All Rights Reserved. Expand By Patrick Connolly | pconnolly@orlandosentinel.com | Orlando Sentinel UPDATED: October 2, 2022 at 9:30 AM EDT The sounds of accordion music and yodeling waft through the air along U.S. 192, drawing visitors into an experience that transports them to Munich, Germany , all without ever leaving Kissimmee. Oktoberfest is in full swing all month at Krush Brau Park, a new attraction that aims to highlight German cuisine and culture. The experience was dreamed up by Waylon Krush, a Washington, D.C., transplant who was inspired by a deployment overseas in the U.S. Army. ‚ÄúI was stationed right outside Munich, Germany, and I went to Oktoberfest three years in a row,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt was the most amazing thing I‚Äôve ever felt. I had to replicate that here.‚Äù Waylon Krush, owner of Krush Brau Park, shows off a plate of German-inspired cuisine in Kissimmee on Sept. 23, 2022. Krush‚Äôs biergarten is set under a tent with imported brews, German cuisine, stein hoisting, lederhosen, shot skis and plenty of entertainment. The venue is what formerly served as home to the Jungleland Zoo, a gem found by Krush‚Äôs real estate agent, who advertised it as a real garden ‚Äî and a fairly overgrown one at that. But the German-inspired experience is just the start and the jumping-off point for what Krush hopes will become a larger cultural experience. In phases, Krush Brau Park is slated to take shape as a cross between Epcot and Boxi Park Lake Nona . The plan is for the attraction to have 13 distinct countries with shops, eateries and structures made  from shipping containers. Stein hoisting is part of the festivities at Krush Brau Park in Kissimmee on Sept. 23, 2022. ‚ÄúOur mission is to create a place where families can come and have a theme park that doesn‚Äôt cost a lot of money,‚Äù Krush said. ‚ÄúI love Disney, but not everyone can afford it.‚Äù Renderings and plans for developing the 10 acres include the Taj Mahal, French and Italian spaces and scenes from China, Japan and Korea. In the Brazilian area, Krush hopes to build a ‚ÄúChrist the Redeemer‚Äù statue out of containers. When this future phase comes to fruition, guests can also visit Canada and indulge in a poutine bar. In paying homage to the former zoo, Krush Brau Park will have animatronic animals. In the meantime, the park‚Äôs phase one will host patrons in the Oktoberfest tent, a space that will transform to entertain guests during the 2022 FIFA World Cup and events such as the Christmastime Weihnachten and ‚ÄúSilvester Fest‚Äù for New Year‚Äôs. ‚ÄúDisco fries‚Äù include bratwurst pieces and a cheese sauce at Krush Brau Park in Kissimmee on Sept. 23, 2022. While crafting his new attraction, Krush brought in seasoned chefs and entertainment professionals from far and wide to support the guest experience. Michael Gogolin, the park‚Äôs executive chef, moved from the Atlanta area and spent time researching German cuisine before his arrival. Now the park features creative dishes such as ‚Äúdisco fries‚Äù ‚Äî featuring cheese sauce and pieces of bratwurst ‚Äî and doner kebab. ‚ÄúEverybody eats meat and potatoes, it‚Äôs just how they‚Äôre prepared. What do they use and why?,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI like to spin it. I‚Äôm not a traditionalist, classic chef.‚Äù German-themed entertainment takes the stage during Oktoberfest at Krush Brau Park in Kissimmee on Friday, Sept. 23, 2022. While Krush and his team have big ambitions for the future attraction, for now, he‚Äôs focusing on throwing the best, most authentic Oktoberfest he can. ‚ÄúPeople get together, you put a tent up. We‚Äôve got good beer, good food, good service and entertainment, and that‚Äôs it,‚Äù Krush said. If you go Krush Brau Park is open 4-11 pm Thursday-Friday, noon-11 p.m. Saturday and noon-8 p.m. Sunday through Oct. 30 at 4580 W. Irlo Bronson Memorial Highway in Kissimmee. General admission is $5 per person; children ages 12 and younger enter for free. Veterans can receive free tickets. For more information, visit krushbraupark.com . When will the biergarten be open? We are currently working on the biergarten now. Fingers crossed, we will be up and running by the end of this Year. How do I find information on events? We will continually update our website and Facebook page as we schedule new events. Are pets/dogs allowed? Yes. We are a dog friendly establishment in all of our outdoor areas. We ask that you to please pick up after your pet and ensure they are on a leash at all times. Will the biergarten have live entertainment? Yes. We hire authentic German musicians, dancers, and artists. Do you have special discounts and tickets for Veterans? Yes. Veterans will receive a 10% discount in our gift shop, as well as a 20% discount on food. Simply show us your ID. Discounted tickets will be available for special events through Vet Tix . What is available in the gift shop? We have German gifts, Krush Brau Park memorabilia, and children's plushies. I see children are allowed - what things are available for them? We are truly a family establishment. Our live entertainment shows in the biergarten and event center are interactive and include fun songs and dances for the children, like the chicken dance. We also provide activity books for all children as they arrive at the biergarten. And our event center has several activities for children including oversized outdoor games. Will you have a Stein Club? Yes - we are currently developing our Stein Club. We will provide additional information about the club and benefits as we get closer to our biergarten grand opening. REGISTER NOW About Summertoberfest Embrace Authentic German Culture Embrace Authentic German Culture Embrace Authentic German Culture At Krush Brau Summertoberfest, we strive to recreate the authentic atmosphere of a traditional Oktoberfest celebration. Immerse yourself in German culture as you explore the vibrant decorations, Bavarian flags, and cheerful staff dressed in traditional attire. From the moment you step through the doors, you'll be transported to the heart of Munich's Oktoberfest, right here in Central Florida - right off 192 close to Disney World! Join us for Happy Hour every Saturday from 12pm-3pm! Raise Your Stein to Live Music Embrace Authentic German Culture Embrace Authentic German Culture Get ready to tap your feet and dance to the lively beats of authentic German music! Our Summertoberfest event will showcase talented musicians who will keep the energy high and the party going all day long. Grab your friends, hit the dance floor, and join in the traditional dances like the Chicken Dance and the Polka. It's a fantastic opportunity to let loose, make unforgettable memories, and experience the joy of Oktoberfest right in the heart of Florida. We will also have the traditional stein holding contests with the winner going to an all expenses paid trip to New York for the world championship. Savor Delightful German Cuisine Embrace Authentic German Culture Savor Delightful German Cuisine No Oktoberfest is complete without indulging in the mouth watering flavors of German cuisine. Krush Brau Summertoberfest will feature a range of delicious traditional dishes that will make your taste buds dance with joy. From hearty bratwursts and pretzels to delectable schnitzels and sauerkraut, there's something to satisfy every craving. Don't forget to pair your food with a Krush Brau stein of our exceptional German beers for the perfect combination! Bring or buy a Krush Brau Stein and enjoy $10 refills all day. Contact Us Don't Just Read About Us, Come Visit Us! Get on down to enjoy German Beer, Food, and Live Music this summer!
